sa14.3:1.2: One time, the Buddha stayed at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta’s Grove in Śrāvastī.
sa14.3:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa14.3:2.3: If a monk cultivates the mindfulness of breathing and cultivates it often, he’ll attain calmness of body and mind.
sa14.3:2.4: He’ll cultivate and fulfill tranquility, purity, and the perceptions of insight with perception and contemplation.
sa14.3:3.1: “How does he attain calmness of body and mind and fulfill tranquility, purity, and the perceptions of insight with perception and contemplation after often cultivating mindfulness of breathing?
sa14.3:4.1: “Suppose this monk lives depending on a village or town.
sa14.3:4.2: In the early morning, he puts on his robe and takes his bowl into the village to solicit alms.
sa14.3:4.3: He protects himself well, guards his faculties, and keeps his mind well restrained.
sa14.3:4.4: After soliciting alms, he returns to his dwelling and puts away his robe and bowl.
sa14.3:4.5: After washing his feet, he either goes to sit under a tree or in a dwelling in a forest or on bare ground out in the open.
sa14.3:4.6: He sits correctly with his body upright and fixes his attention in front of him.
sa14.3:4.7: He stops worldly cravings and secludes himself from desire purely.
sa14.3:4.12: Freed from doubt and confusion, he attains certainty about the mind’s good qualities.
sa14.3:5.1: “He’s secluded from the five hindrances and disturbances in his mind that weaken the powers of wisdom, block discernment, and lead not to nirvāṇa.
sa14.3:5.2: He’s mindful of internal calming, training well and fixing his attention.
sa14.3:5.3: He’s mindful external calming, training well fixing his attention.
sa14.3:6.3: He perceives his whole body as he inhales.
sa14.3:6.4: He trains well regarding the whole body as he inhales.
sa14.3:6.5: He perceives his whole body as he exhales.
sa14.3:6.6: He trains well regarding the whole body as he exhales.
sa14.3:6.7: He perceives his whole body’s activity calm as he inhales.
sa14.3:6.8: He trains well regarding the whole body’s activity calming as he inhales.
sa14.3:6.9: He perceives his whole body’s activity calm as he exhales.
sa14.3:6.10: He trains well regarding the whole body’s activity calming as he exhales.
sa14.3:7.4: perceives mental activity calm as he inhales.
sa14.3:7.5: He trains well, perceiving mental activity calming as he inhales.
sa14.3:7.6: He perceives mental activity calm as he exhales.
sa14.3:7.7: He trains well, perceiving mental activity calming as he exhales.
sa14.3:8.4: perceives his mind’s liberation as he inhales.
sa14.3:8.5: He trains well, perceiving his mind’s liberation as he inhales.
sa14.3:8.6: He perceives his mind’s liberation as he exhales.
sa14.3:8.7: He trains well, perceiving his mind’s liberation as he exhales.
sa14.3:9.5: He trains well regarding the observation of cessation as he inhales.
sa14.3:9.6: He observes cessation as he exhales.
sa14.3:9.7: He trains well regarding the observation of cessation as he exhales.
sa14.3:10.1: “This is called cultivating the mindfulness of breathing.
sa14.3:10.2: The body is calmed, and the mind is calmed.
sa14.3:10.3: Tranquility, purity, and the perceptions of insight are cultivated and fulfilled with perception and contemplation.”
sa14.3:11.1: After the Buddha taught this sutra, the monks who heard what he taught rejoiced and handed it down.
